questions.text: A patient with a left-sided C6-7 herniated nucleolus pulposus would likely have which of the following constellation of findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Pain in the thumb, triceps weakness, and loss of triceps reflex

options.label: B
options.text: Middle finger numbness, wrist extensor weakness, and diminished brachioradialis reflex

options.label: C
options.text: Thumb numbness, wrist extensor weakness, and diminished brachioradialis reflex

options.label: D
options.text: Middle finger numbness, triceps weakness, and loss of triceps reflex

questions.correct_answer: D. Middle finger numbness, triceps weakness, and loss of triceps reflex
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Middle finger numbness, triceps weakness, and loss of triceps reflex Middle finger numbness, triceps weakness, and loss of triceps reflex-correct statement. A C6-7 herniation affects the C7 root. The C7 root has the middle finger as its predominant sensory distribution. Its motor function is the triceps, wrist extension, and metacarpophalangeal finger extension. The reflex is the triceps.

Its motor function is the triceps, wrist extension, and metacarpophalangeal finger extension. The reflex is the triceps. Pain in the thumb is less likely Option: B. brachioradialis reflex is C5 and C6 rather than C7. Option: C. Thumb numbness and diminished brachioradialis reflex will not be present.

questions.text: What is the most likely consequence of a vertebral compression fracture associated with osteoporosis?

options.label: A
options.text: The fractured vertebral body gradually becomes stiffer than before the fracture

options.label: C
options.text: There is an increased risk of more vertebral fractures

options.label: D
options.text: Overall sagittal alignment remains stable because the adjacent segments of the spine are able to compensate

questions.correct_answer: C. There is an increased risk of more vertebral fractures
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is an increased risk of more vertebral fractures After an osteoporotic vertebral compression fracture , the risk of subsequent fractures at adjacent levels increases . This is thought to be the result of a shifting of the sagittal alignment more anteriorly, putting more stress on the osteopenic vertebral bodies and their anterior cortices. Pain generally resolves with rest, but this may take weeks or months. It has been demonstrated experimentally that osteoporotic vertebral bodies are less stiff and weaker after a compression fracture ; therefore, deformity predisposes further deformity. The extensor musculature often fatigues over time and usually does not hypertrophy. The frontal plane deformity is a rare development.

Highyeild:

Essential features of different types of spinal injuries Mechanism Type of injury Common site Column failure X-ray features Stability Flexion injury e.g., Fall on buttock/head, Heavy object falling on flexed spine Compression fracture L 1 >L 2 >D 12 Only anterior column failure Diminished anterior height of vertebra, posterior part remains intact Stable Flexion-rotation injury e.g., Fall on one side, Blow on the side Fracture- dislocation L 1 , D 12 C 3 , C 7 All the three columns failure Direct evidence (subluxation/dislocation) • Posterior arch fracture • Broken facets • Vertebral body offset anteriorly Indirect evidence • Broken ribs • Broken transverse processes • Increased disc height • Increased interspinous distance Unstable Vertical compression injury e.g., Object falling on head Burst fracture C 3 , C 6 Anterior & middle columns failure Diminished anterior and posterior heights of vertebra CT scan may be of help in demonstrating compromise of the spinal canal by bony fragments May be unstable Extension injury e.g., Motor vehicle accident, Shallow water diving Avulsion fracture of anterior lip of vertebra C 3 , C 6 Only anterior column failure Small chip from margin of vertebra, CT scan of no help Stable Flexion-distraction injury e.g., Car seat belt injury Chance fracture Dorsal spine Middle & posterior column failure Horizontal fracture line through posterior arch and posterior part of body of the vertebra May be unstable Direct injury e.g., Bullet injury, Muscle contraction Fracture of spinous or transverse processes Any region Any/All columns failure Variable Variable

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The fractured vertebral body gradually collapses rather becoming more stiff. Option: B. Scoliosis – lateral bending of the spine is less likely to develop. Option: D. Overall sagittal alignment does not remain stable

questions.text: The vertebral artery typically enters the spine via the transverse foramen of which of the following vertebrae?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C6 The vertebral artery is the first branch of the subclavian artery. It ascends through the foramina in the transverse processes of the upper six cervical vertebrae. Then it winds behind the superior articular process of the atlas and enters the skull through the foramen magnum. The vertebral artery is the first branch of the subclavian artery. It ascends through the foramina in the transverse processes of the upper six cervical vertebrae. Then it winds behind the superior articular process of the atlas and enters the skull through the foramen magnum.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

C7 In the hand, the thumb is supplied by C6, the index, middle, and ring fingers by C7, and the little finger by C8.The c7 nerve root also has the motor supply to the muscles causing elbow flexion and wrist extension. So any injury to this nerve root causes corresponding muscle. In the hand, the thumb is supplied by C6, the index, middle, and ring fingers by C7, and the little finger by C8. The c7 nerve root also has the motor supply to the muscles causing elbow flexion and wrist extension. So any injury to this nerve root causes corresponding muscle.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man complains of pain in his buttocks and the back of his legs. The pain is exacerbated by walking and is relieved by leaning forward What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spinal stenosis This clinical scenario is typical of patients with spinal stenosis . This condition results from the narrowing of the spinal canal , which causes nerve root or cord compression, leading to persistent pain in the buttocks, limping, lack of sensation in the lower extremities, and decreased physical activity

Highyeild:

Spinal stenosis, a narrowing of the spaces in your spine, can compress your spinal cord and nerve roots exiting each vertebra. Age-related changes in your spine are a common cause. Symptoms include back and/or neck pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in your arms and legs. Treatments are self-care remedies, physical therapy, medications, injections, and surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In Spondylolisthesis, pain is not relieved by leaning forward. Option: B. in Sciatica, pain is not relieved by leaning forward. Option: C. In Cauda equine syndrome, pain is not relieved by leaning forward.

questions.text: You are called to the emergency department to evaluate an 82-year-old woman who became confused in the middle of the night and fell while getting out of bed Her current medical history includes Alzheimer's dementia, diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Her son reports that 8 years ago she had a heart attack that was treated with a cardiac stent. Initial radiographs indicate a minimally displaced type II odontoid fracture. The optimal treatment for this patient's fracture is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cervical collar This patient has multiple comorbidities that make her a suboptimal surgical candidate. Furthermore, in the case of a minimally displaced type II odontoid fracture, it is more than acceptable to definitively treat an elderly, demented patient with a rigid cervical collar for 6 to 12 weeks. Though treatment with a cervical collar can have lower rates of bone healing than surgery, the fibrous union is generally sufficient in a low-demand individual.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Use of a halo vest is associated with high rates of complications, especially aspiration, in the elderly population and has not demonstrated superior outcomes to cervical collars. As stated, this patient is a poor surgical candidate, owing to her significant past medical history, making choices C and D less than ideal. Option: C. An odontoid screw reQuires adeQuate bone density for proper fixation, and this patient is likely to have osteoporotic bone given her age, gender, and history of diabetes. Option: D. As stated, this patient is a poor surgical candidate, owing to her significant past medical history, making choices C and D less than ideal.

questions.text: When a person falls from height and lands on his feet the chances of spinal injury are very high, the area in the vertebral column most likely to sustain an injury is the?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dorsolumbar junction Fractures and dislocations of the spine are serious injuries because they may be associated with damage to the spinal cord or cauda equine. The thoracolumbar s egment is the commonest site of injury ; the lower cervical is the next most common.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Coccyx is less likely to be injured. Option: C. Cervical spine is less likely injured. Option: D. Lumbo sacral junction is less likely injured.

questions.text: Burst spine fracture is a type of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Compression injury It is a vertical compression type of injury. When two columns are disrupted (a burst fracture of the body of the vertebra) the spine is considered unstable. In the cervical spine, this force results in a burst fracture i.e., the vertebral body is crushed throughout its vertical dimensions. A piece of bone or disc may get displaced into the spinal canal, causing pressure on the cord.

Highyeild:

It is a vertical compression type of injury When two columns are disrupted ( a burst fracture of the body of the vertebra ) the spine is considered unstable. In the cervical spine, this force results in a burst fracture i.e., the vertebral body is crushed throughout its vertical dimensions. A piece of bone or disc may get displaced into the spinal canal, causing pressure on the cord.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Not Flexion injury Option: B. Not. Extension injury Option: D. Not rotational injury.Burst fracture

questions.text: Motorcyclist's fracture is?

options.label: A
options.text: Ring fracture of base of skull

options.label: B
options.text: Hinge fracture of base of skull

questions.correct_answer: B. Hinge fracture of base of skull
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hinge fracture of base of skull Motorcyclist's fracture is a hinge fracture of the skull base

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Not motorcyclist’s fracture Option: C. Not motorcyclist’s fracture Option: D. Not motorcyclist’s fracture

Extraedge:

Additional information: From the entrance exams point of view Motorcyclist's fracture is a ring fracture of the skull base. Most common cause of spinal cord injury in India (developing countries) is fall from height whereas in developed countries, it is road traffic accidents. Dislocation without fracture can be seen in the cervical spine. Vertebroplasty: Polymethylmethacrylate is injected into fractured (compressed) vertebral bod ies to decrease pain and strengthen the bone. This does not restore the height of the verte- brae or prevent deformity. Baloon kyphoplasty: A small balloon is inflated in the compressed vertebral body to restore its height and alignment. Both procedures are absolutely contraindicated in infection, untreated coagulopathy and healed osteoporotic fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding cervical whiplash injury is wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: Usually occurs when the neck is suddenly jerked into hyperextension

options.label: B
options.text: The anterior longitudinal ligament is likely strained or torn and discs may be damaged

options.label: C
options.text: Complaints may be pain and stiffness which may be quite intractable and take up to a year to resolve

options.label: D
options.text: Usually occurs when the neck is suddenly compressed as a load falling on the head

questions.correct_answer: D. Usually occurs when the neck is suddenly compressed as a load falling on the head
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Usually occurs when the neck is suddenly compressed as a load falling on the head

Highyeild:

Whiplash Injury It is the acceleration, deceleration injury of the cervical spine caused usually by collision. There is hyperextension followed by flexion of spine. It commonly affects the cervical column. This is also known as 'sprained neck' as only soft tissue is involved. There is usually no vertebral involvement. Clinical presentation Pain is a typical feature, usually appearing on day one of injury. Stiffness of neck, local tenderness and decreased range of motion Nerve root compression can lead to paresthesias in the region of distribution of that nerve. In case of associated retropharyngeal hematoma there can be dysphagia. Investigation X-Ray of cervical spine appear normal There is straightening out or reversal of the normal cervical lordosis, suggestive of muscle spasm. Treatment Initial bed rest, NSAIDs and soft collar immobilization Physiotherapy and mobilization exercises If spine is unstable then posterior fusion can be done

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Correct statement Option: B. Correct statement Option: C. Correct statement

questions.text: Whiplash injury is caused due to?

options.label: C
options.text: A blow on top to head

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute hyperextension of the spine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute hyperextension of the spine This injury is commonly seen in the cervical spine. In a Motor vehicle accident – the forehead strikes against the windscreen forcing the neck into hyperextension; This injury results in a chip fracture of the anterior rim of a vertebra and may be unstable.

Highyeild:

Whiplash Injury It is the acceleration, deceleration injury of the cervical spine caused usually by collision. There is hyperextension followed by flexion of spine. It commonly affects the cervical column. This is also known as 'sprained neck' as only soft tissue is involved. There is usually no vertebral involvement. Clinical presentation Pain is a typical feature, usually appearing on day one of injury. Stiffness of neck, local tenderness and decreased range of motion Nerve root compression can lead to paresthesias in the region of distribution of that nerve. In case of associated retropharyngeal hematoma there can be dysphagia. Investigation X-Ray of cervical spine appear normal There is straightening out or reversal of the normal cervical lordosis, suggestive of muscle spasm. Treatment Initial bed rest, NSAIDs and soft collar immobilization Physiotherapy and mobilization exercises If spine is unstable then posterior fusion can be done EXTENSION INJURY This injury is commonly seen in the cervical spine. In a Motor vehicle accident – the forehead strikes against the windscreen forcing the neck into hyperextension; This injury results in a chip fracture of the anterior rim of a vertebra and may be unstable.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Not due to fall from height Option: C. Not due to a blow on top of the head. Option: D. Not due to hyperflexion of the spine.

questions.text: Which of the following vertebral fractures involves disruption of ligaments of anterior, middle, and posterior columns:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chance fracture Chance fracture It’s a horizontal fracture extending into the posterior elements and involving a body part. It is an unstable injury The tear passes transversely through the bones or the ligament structures, or both. The split runs through the spinous process, the transverse processes, the pedicles, and the vertebral body.

Highyeild:

Distraction injuries Flexion-distraction injury (Chance fracture) . Seen most commonly at upper lumbar spine. On impact, there is flexion of the lumbar spine due to lap belt and injury occurs as the bone and ligament both fail in tension around the center of rotation created by seat belt, which is anterior to the anterior longitudinal ligament. Combined flexion & distraction may cause mid lumbar spine to 'Jack Knife' around an axis that is placed anterior to the vertebral column leading to vertebral body fail in flexion and posterior & middle element fail in distraction. It compresses the abdominal content against the anterior spine also. These type of injuries are most commonly seen in motor vehicle accidents so also known as "Seat belt injuries"/ jack Knife / Chance fracture

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In Clay shoveller's fracture, disruption of ligaments of anterior, middle, and posterior columns is not seen. Option: B. In a Wedge compression fracture, disruption of ligaments of the anterior, middle, and posterior columns is not seen. Option: D. In Jefferson's fracture , disruption of ligaments of anterior, middle, and posterior columns is not seen.

Halocast Halo brace provides the best control at cervical spine

questions.text: Postural scoliosis is differentiated from structural scoliosis because the?

options.label: A
options.text: Postural curve disappears on lying down

options.label: B
options.text: Structural curve is usually seen in the lumbar spine

options.label: C
options.text: The postural curve disappears on forward flexion

options.label: D
options.text: Structural curve disappears on correction of limb length discrepancy

questions.correct_answer: C. The postural curve disappears on forward flexion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The postural curve disappears on forward flexion Postural scoliosis: It is the commonest overall type, often seen in adolescent girls. The curve is mild and convex, usually to the left. The main diagnostic feature is that the curve straightens completely when the patient bends forwards

Highyeild:

Scoliosis Scoliosis is lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the vertebrae. The word scoliosis in Greek means "crooked". It is also defined as lateral deviation of the normal vertical line of the spine, which when measured on a radiograph, is greater than 10 degrees It can be classified as Congenital There is failure in vertebral formation or segmentation of the involved vertebrae. Idiopathic This is the most common type. The cause is unknown. Congenital Scoliosis Classification Failure of formation Partial failure (wedge vertebrae) Complete failure (hemivertebrae Failure of segmentation Unilateral failure (Unsegmented bar) Bilateral failure (Block vertebrae) Postural scoliosis: ● It is the commonest overall type, often seen in adolescent girls. ● The curve is mild and convex, usually to the left. ● The main diagnostic feature is that the curve straightens completely when the patient bends forwards Structural scoliosis: ● It is a scoliosis with a component of permanent deformity. The following are the different subtypes: o Idiopathic o Congenital o Paralytic

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. A- Postural curve does not disappear on lying down Option: B. Postural and Structural curves both seen in the lumbar spine. Option: D. Structural curve will not disappear on correction of limb length discrepancy.

questions.text: The Cobb method is used for which of the following?

options.label: D
options.text: Measurement of curves in scoliosis of spine

questions.correct_answer: D. Measurement of curves in scoliosis of spine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Measurement of curves in scoliosis of spine To measure curves in scoliosis of the spine. The severity of the curve is measured by Cobb's angle –the angle between the line passing through the margins of the vertebrae at the ends of the curve

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Not to measure anteversion of femur Option: B. Not to measure Patellar tilt Option: C. Not to measure Placement of cup in THR

questions.text: All the following are true regarding cervical spondylitis except?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a degenerative disorder of the cervical spine seen in people over 50 years of age usually

options.label: B
options.text: Occurs early in persons pursuing white-collar jobs

options.label: C
options.text: It is more common in the lower cervical spine usually C5-C6

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical compression is usually the first line of management in all cases of cervical spondylitis

questions.correct_answer: D. Surgical compression is usually the first line of management in all cases of cervical spondylitis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgical compression is usually the first line of management in all cases of cervical spondylitis The symptoms of cervical spondylosis undergo spontaneous remissions and exacerbations. Treatment is aimed at assisting the natural resolution of the temporarily inflamed soft tissues. Surgical compression is not the first line of management in cases of cervical spondylitis

Highyeild:

CERVICAL SPONDYLOSIS It is a degenerative condition of the cervical spine found almost universally in persons over 50 years of age. It occurs early in persons pursuing 'white collar jobs' or those susceptible to neck strain because of keeping the neck constantly in one position while reading, writing, etc. PATHOLOGY The pathology begins in the intervertebral discs. Degeneration of disc results in a reduction of disc space and peripheral osteophyte formation. The osteophytes impinging on the nerve roots give rise to radicular pain in the upper limb. Exceptionally, the osteophytes may press on the spinal cord, giving rise to signs of cord compression. Cervical spondylosis occurs most commonly in the lowest three cervical intervertebral joints (the commonest is at C5-C6). CLINICAL FEATURES Pain and stiffness Giddiness Radiating pain TREATMENT The symptoms of cervical spondylosis undergo spontaneous remissions and exacerbations. Treatment is aimed at assisting the natural resolution of the temporarily inflamed soft tissues.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It is a degenerative condition of the cervical spine found almost universally in persons over 50 years of age. Option: B. It occurs early in persons pursuing 'white collar jobs' or those susceptible to neck strain because of keeping the neck constantly in one position while reading, writing, etc. Option: C. It is more common in the lower cervical spine usually C5-C6

questions.text: Scoliosis is defined by which curvature of the spine:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Convex side Curvature is defined by the convex side of the spine. It is the commonest overall type, often seen in adolescent girls. The curve is mild and convex, usually to the left. The main diagnostic feature is that the curve straightens completely when the patient bends forwards

Highyeild:

Spondylolysthesis Before we learn about spondylolysthesis, we must be very clear about different terminology used in relation to spine these are Spondylosis: It refers to degenerative change in the spine Spondylitis: It refers to inflammatory changes in the spine Spondylolysis: It refers to breach in Pars interarticularis Spondylolysis is defined as a break at pars interarticularis. This can be present without any spondylolisthesis. Most often there are complaints of back pain and sometimes with leg pain as well. On examination there is localized pain, most commonly in the midline at the lumbosacral junction. DIAGNOSIS X ray oblique view is best to evaluate spondylolysis. This shows a break at the pars interarticularis. It is often labeled as Scottish terrier sign which refers to the normal appearance of the lumbar spine seen on oblique radiographic projection, where one or other part of verterbra joins to give appearance of Scottish terrier, like the pars interarticularis makes the neck of the dog and the ear is by superior articular facet. CT scan can give the best information. Treatment Depending on complaints/symptoms of patient it can be conservative or surgical fixation Spondylolysthesis: It has been derived from greek "spondylo" means spine and "olisthesis" means slip. In this condition one vertebrae slips over another vertebrae. The backward displacement is known as retrolisthesis. Most common level involved is L5-S1 followed by L4-L5.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Not right side Option: B. Not left side Option: C. Not concave side.

questions.text: Risser sign is seen to evaluate the progression of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scoliosis A- Radiological assessment regarding the likelihood of progression of the curve in scoliosis can be made by looking at the iliac apophysis . It fuses with the iliac bone at maturity and indicates the completion of growth, and thus no possibility of the curve worsening. This is called Reisser's sign.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Not kyphosis Option: C. Not lordosis Option: D. Not spondylolysis

questions.text: Milwaukee brace is used for which of the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scoliosis Non-operative methods for scoliosis: Non-operative methods for scoliosis: These consist of exercises to tone up the spinal muscles and give support to the spine. Following supports are commonly used: Milwaukee brace: This is named after the city of Milwaukee where it was designed. Boston brace: It is cosmetically more acceptable. Reisser's turn-buckle cast: This is a body cast with a turn-buckle in between. Tightening of the turn Fig buckle stretches the concave side of the curve, thus correcting the deformity. Localiser cast: This is a body cast applied with the spine in traction. A special localizer table is required for this.

questions.text: A 9 yr old boy presents to the OPD with complaints of shoulder elevation and a rib rotation deformity. Her x-ray reveals right-side thoracic scoliosis. Which of the following is Risser staging used to determine?

options.label: C
options.text: The skeletal maturity of the patient

questions.correct_answer: C. The skeletal maturity of the patient
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The skeletal maturity of the patient Risser staging is: The Risser sign is an indirect measure of skeletal maturity, whereby the degree of ossification of the iliac apophysis by x-ray evaluation is used to judge overall skeletal development . Mineralization of the iliac apophyses begins at the anterolateral crest and progresses medially toward the spine. Fusion of the calcified apophyses to the ilium then progresses in the opposite direction, from medial to lateral.

Highyeild:

A typical five-point grading scale is as follows: Grade 1 is given when the ilium (bone) is calcified at a level of 25%; it corresponds to prepuberty or early puberty. Grade 2 is given when the ilium (bone) is calcified at a level of 50%; it corresponds to the stage before or during a growth spurt. Grade 3 is given when the ilium (bone) is calcified at a level of 75%; it corresponds to the slowing of growth. Grade 4 is given when the ilium (bone) is calcified at a level of 100%; it corresponds to an almost cessation of growth. Grade 5 is given when the ilium (bone) is calcified at a level of 100% and the iliac apophysis is fused to the iliac crest; it corresponds to the end of growth. Risser grading is traditionally used to estimate the future growth potential of the adolescent spine, particularly in the setting of spinal scoliosis. Risser originally recognized that the ossification of the iliac apophysis approximately parallels the ossification of the vertebral apophyses. The earlier the stage of growth, the greater the likelihood of scoliosis progressing and potentially needing intervention.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Not type of curve Option: B. Indirectly it is used to know the risk of curve progression as per skeletal maturity. Option: D. Not for the appropriate level of fusion.
